instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message:
Gets green light, then orange light. Has battery voltage.  Has 3v s5 and 5v s5.  no s4, no power to efi chip.   Feels like SMC issue to me, but would be much happier if it were something else.

Dust everywhere (cleaned) but nothing that looks like liquid damage anywhere.  Fan was completely packed with an inch of dust, some im guessing she has been cooking for quite some time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Did you try original 60/85W charger?
Does it start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>,  3.451




<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>,  0




<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, 3.329




<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, 0




<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, 3.45




<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, 3.212




<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. 3.488


Original 60w as well as thunderbolt display ( which i think is a built in 85W)

No difference with SMC bypass

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7940</CHIP> voltages.
If <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is also low, usually means incorrect charger.
Try known good original charger.
Or try to start with battery connected at same time; with some charge on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message: Whatever is going on must be intermittent.  for no obvious reason i got 3v sus at the efi chip and the cpu got warm.  fan wasn't plugged in so couldn't verify fan spin.  Unplugged to plug in LCD, gone.   Trying charger and battery dance with no change.   Seems to be a slight barely visible flicker on the charger light

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message: Put good flux and reflow SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message:
no luck. Battery has a charge on it for sure. Reflowed smc with no clean flux. Nothing changed. stomped away in anger left it plugged in to 60W charger. came back in the room a half hour later and it was running and booted up. shutdown, tried to turn on again, nothing. Back to no EFI chip power


EDIT:  Reflowed smc again.  now get consistent fan spin with power button and charger plug in.  No chime no display internal or external

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  Green light, Orange light no power
threads.message:
Reball SMC.
If no result, then change it.
It could got damaged in the two reflows; or some balls melt underneath.
